entry.title: #55 - Homebrew with Mike McQuaid
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre developing on macOS, then you probably know what we‚Äôre going to talk about: Homebrew üç∫ the most popular package manager for macOS.

If you don‚Äôt know Homebrew, it‚Äôs a command-line tool that allows you to install software on your Mac. We could call it ‚Äúthe missing app store‚Äù for your console. But Homebrew is much more than that! There is an entire ecosystem of contributors that maintain formulas to make it easy to install software on your Mac.

Today I have the honor to speak with Mike McQuaid, the Homebrew project leader. In this episode we‚Äôre going to talk about how Homebrew started, how it works internally, how it‚Äôs funded, and how you can contribute to it. I‚Äôm glad I also had the chance to touch on some more contentious topics like telemetry and handling burnout in the OSS space.

entry.title: #53 - thanks.dev with Armin Nehzat
entry.content:
Today we don‚Äôt talk about a specific Open Source project, but about a tool that can help us build a more sustainable ecosystem: thanks.dev.

I have the pleasure to have on stage Armin Nehzat, Growth Officer of thanks.dev, a donation and sponsoring platform for open-source projects.

The key feature of thanks.dev is how it manages to scan your dependency tree and discovers all the projects you build on top, so you can split your donations to all of them. Similarly as a maintainer, you can get a fraction of a donation, even if you‚Äôre down in the dependency chain of someone else.

Join us in this episode as Armin walk us through the challenges of connecting donors with maintainers in a sustainable way.
